title: Letter: Betjeman and Mitford and suburban floral snobbery
text:
Robin Lane Fox (“Through Mitford's eyes”, House & Home, FT Weekend, June 12) clearly shares the same view as Nancy Mitford where “every tree appeared to be entirely covered with a waving mass of pink or mauve tissue paper” creating a riot of sterility.

For Lane Fox, “you can still tell when you are well south of the Thames, in East Sheen or Tulse Hill, by the volume of crude pink double blossom on the street trees”. For me, however, I'm far happier to take my lead from the poet John Betjeman, who finds in Camberley “The drawing room is done in pink / The other rooms are mauve, I think” and “Pear and apple in Croydon gardens bud and blossom and fall”.

Christopher Gibbs
Villars, France
